Shes a sensitive , affectionate , anxious soul ; and she was never brought up to know what freedom is to some people . You see , family life is all the life she knows : she 's like a bird born in a cage , that would die if you let it loose in the woods . When I thought how little it was to a man of my easy temper to put up with her , and how deep it would hurt her to think it was because I didnt care for her , I always put off running away till next time ; and so in the end I never ran away at all . I daresay it was good for me to be took such care of ; but it cut me off from all my old friends something dreadful , maam : especially the women , maam . She never gave them a chance : she didnt indeed . She never understood that married people should take holidays from one another if they are to keep at all fresh . Not that I ever got tired of her , maam ; but my ! how I used to get tired of home life sometimes . I used to catch myself envying my brother George : I positively did , maam .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: George was a bachelor then , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: Bless you , no , maam . He married a very fine figure of a woman ; but she was that changeable and what you might call susceptible , you would not believe . She didnt seem to have any control over herself when she fell in love . She would mope for a couple of days , crying about nothing ; and then she would up and say — no matter who was there to hear her — “ I must go to him , George ” ; and away she would go from her home and her husband without with-your-leave or by-your-leave .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: But do you mean that she did this more than once ? That she came back ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: Bless you , maam , she done it five times to my own knowledge ; and then George gave up telling us about it , he got so used to it .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: But did he always take her back ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: Well , what could he do , maam ? Three times out of four the men would bring her back the same evening and no harm done . Other times theyd run away from her . What could any man with a heart do but comfort her when she came back crying at the way they dodged her when she threw herself at their heads , pretending they was too noble to accept the sacrifice she was making . George told her again and again that if she 'd only stay at home and hold off a bit theyd be at her feet all day long . She got sensible at last and took his advice . George always liked change of company .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: What an odious woman , Collins ! Dont you think so ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: judiciallyWell , many ladies with a domestic turn thought so and said so , maam . But I will say for Mrs George that the variety of experience made her wonderful interesting . Thats where the flighty ones score off the steady ones , maam . Look at my old woman ! She 's never known any man but me ; and she cant properly know me , because she dont know other men to compare me with . Of course she knows her parents in — well , in the way one does know one 's parents not knowing half their lives as you might say , or ever thinking that they was ever young ; and she knew her children as children , and never thought of them as independent human beings till they ran away and nigh broke her heart for a week or two . But Mrs George she came to know a lot about men of all sorts and ages ; for the older she got the younger she liked em ; and it certainly made her interesting , and gave her a lot of sense . I have often taken her advice on things when my own poor old woman wouldnt have been a bit of use to me .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: I hope you dont tell your wife that you go elsewhere for advice .

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: Lord bless you , maam , I 'm that fond of my old Matilda that I never tell her anything at all for fear of hurting her feelings . You see , she 's such an out-and-out wife and mother that she 's hardly a responsible human being out of her house , except when she 's marketing .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Does she approve of Mrs George ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: Oh , Mrs George gets round her . Mrs George can get round anybody if she wants to . And then Mrs George is very particular about religion . And shes a clairvoyant .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: surprisedA clairvoyant !

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: calmOh yes , maam , yes . All you have to do is to mesmerize her a bit ; and off she goes into a trance , and says the most wonderful things ! not things about herself , but as if it was the whole human race giving you a bit of its mind . Oh , wonderful , maam , I assure you . You couldnt think of a game that Mrs George isnt up to . Lesbia Grantham comes in through the tower . She is a tall , handsome , slender lady in her prime ; that is , between 36 and 55 . She has what is called a well-bred air , dressing very carefully to produce that effect without the least regard for the latest fashions , sure of herself , very terrifying to the young and shy , fastidious to the ends of her long finger-tips , and tolerant and amused rather than sympathetic .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Good morning , dear big sister .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Good morning , dear little sister .They kiss

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Good morning , Collins . How well you are looking ! And how young !She turns the middle chair away from the table and sits down

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: Thats only my professional habit at a wedding , Miss . You should see me at a political dinner . I look nigh seventy .Looking at his watchTime 's getting along , maam . May I send up word from you to Miss Edith to hurry a bit with her dressing ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Do , Collins . Collins goes out through the tower , taking the cake with him .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Dear old Collins ! Has he told you any stories this morning ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Yes . You were just late for a particularly thrilling invention of his .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: About Mrs George ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Yes . He says she 's a clairvoyant .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: I wonder whether he really invented George , or stole her out of some book .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: I wonder !

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Wheres the Barmecide ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: In the study , working away at his new book . He thinks no more now of having a daughter married than of having an egg for breakfast . The General , soothed by smoking , comes in from the garden .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: with resolute bonhomieAh , Lesbia !

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: How do you do ?They shake hands ; and he takes the chair on her rightMrs Bridgenorth goes out through the tower .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: How are you , Boxer ? You look almost as gorgeous as the wedding cake .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I make a point of appearing in uniform whenever I take part in any ceremony , as a lesson to the subalterns . It is not the custom in England ; but it ought to be .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: You look very fine , Boxer . What a frightful lot of bravery all these medals must represent !

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: No , Lesbia . They represent despair and cowardice . I won all the early ones by trying to get killed . You know why .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: But you had a charmed life ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Yes , a charmed life . Bayonets bent on my buckles . Bullets passed through me and left no trace : thats the worst of modern bullets : Ive never been hit by a dum-dum . When I was only a company officer I had at least the right to expose myself to death in the field . Now I 'm a General even that resource is cut off .Persuasively drawing his chair nearer to herListen to me , Lesbia . For the tenth and last time —

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: interruptingOn Florence 's wedding morning , two years ago , you said “ For the ninth and last time . ”

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: We are two years older , Lesbia . I 'm fifty : you are —

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Yes , I know . It 's no use , Boxer . When will you be old enough to take no for an answer ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Never , Lesbia , never . You have never given me a real reason for refusing me yet . I once thought it was somebody else . There were lots of fellows after you ; but now theyve all given it up and married .Bending still nearer to herLesbia : tell me your secret . Why —

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: sniffing disgustedlyOh ! Youve been smoking .She rises and goes to the chair on the hearthKeep away , you wretch .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: But for that pipe , I could not have faced you without breaking down . It has soothed me and nerved me .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: sitting down with The Times in her handWell , it has nerved me to tell you why I 'm going to be an old maid .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: impulsively approaching herDont say that , Lesbia . It 's not natural : it 's not right : it 's —

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: fanning him offNo : no closer , Boxer , please .He retreats , discouragedIt may not be natural ; but it happens all the time . Youll find plenty of women like me , if you care to look for them : women with lots of character and good looks and money and offers , who wont and dont get married . Cant you guess why ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I can understand when there is another .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Yes ; but there isnt another . Besides , do you suppose I think , at my time of life , that the difference between one decent sort of man and another is worth bothering about ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: The heart has its preferences , Lesbia . One image , and one only , gets indelibly —

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Yes . Excuse my interrupting you so often ; but your sentiments are so correct that I always know what you are going to say before you finish . You see , Boxer , everybody is not like you . You are a sentimental noodle : you dont see women as they really are . You dont see me as I really am . Now I do see men as they really are . I see you as you really are .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: murmuringNo : dont say that , Lesbia .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: I 'm a regular old maid . I 'm very particular about my belongings . I like to have my own house , and to have it to myself . I have a very keen sense of beauty and fitness and cleanliness and order . I am proud of my independence and jealous for it . I have a sufficiently well-stocked mind to be very good company for myself if I have plenty of books and music . The one thing I never could stand is a great lout of a man smoking all over my house and going to sleep in his chair after dinner , and untidying everything . Ugh !

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: But love —

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Ob , love ! Have you no imagination ? Do you think I have never been in love with wonderful men ? heroes ! archangels ! princes ! sages ! even fascinating rascals ! and had the strangest adventures with them ? Do you know what it is to look at a mere real man after that ? a man with his boots in every corner , and the smell of his tobacco in every curtain ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: somewhat dazedWell but — excuse my mentioning it — dont you want children ?

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: I ought to have children . I should be a good mother to children . I believe it would pay the country very well to pay me very well to have children . But the country tells me that I cant have a child in my house without a man in it too ; so I tell the country that it will have to do without my children . If I am to be a mother , I really cannot have a man bothering me to be a wife at the same time .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: My dear Lesbia : you know I dont wish to be impertinent ; but these are not the correct views for an English lady to express .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: That is why I dont express them , except to gentlemen who wont take any other answer . The difficulty , you see , is that I really am an English lady , and am particularly proud of being one .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I 'm sure of that , Lesbia : quite sure of it . I never meant —

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: rising impatientlyOh , my dear Boxer , do please try to think of something else than whether you have offended me , and whether you are doing the correct thing as an English gentleman . You are faultless , and very dull .She shakes her shoulders intolerantly and walks across to the other side of the kitchen

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: moodilyHa ! thats whats the matter with me . Not clever . A poor silly soldier man .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: The whole matter is very simple . As I say , I am an English lady , by which I mean that I have been trained to do without what I cant have on honorable terms , no matter what it is .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I really dont understand you , Lesbia .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: turning on himThen why on earth do you want to marry a woman you dont understand ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I dont know . I suppose I love you .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Well , Boxer , you can love me as much as you like , provided you look happy about it and dont bore me . But you cant marry me ; and thats all about it .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: It 's so frightfully difficult to argue the matter fairly with you without wounding your delicacy by overstepping the bounds of good taste . But surely there are calls of nature — LESBIA . Dont be ridiculous , Boxer .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Well , how am I to express it ? Hang it all , Lesbia , dont you want a husband ?

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: No . I want children ; and I want to devote myself entirely to my children , and not to their father . The law will not allow me to do that ; so I have made up my mind to have neither husband nor children .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: But , great Heavens , the natural appetites —

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: As I said before , an English lady is not the slave of her appetites . That is what an English gentleman seems incapable of understanding .She sits down at the end of the table , near the study door

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: huffilyOh well , if you refuse , you refuse . I shall not ask you again . I 'm sorry I returned to the subject .He retires to the hearth and plants himself there , wounded and lofty

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Dont be cross , Boxer .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I 'm not cross , only wounded , Lesbia . And when you talk like that , I dont feel convinced : I only feel utterly at a loss .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Well , you know our family rule . When at a loss consult the greengrocer .Opportunely Collins comes in through the towerHere he is .

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: Sorry to be so much in and out , Miss . I thought Mrs Bridgenorth was here . The table is ready now for the breakfast , if she would like to see it .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: If you are satisfied , Collins , I am sure she will be .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: By the way , Collins : I thought theyd made you an alderman .

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: So they have , General .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Then wheres your gown ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: I dont wear it in private life , General .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Why ? Are you ashamed of it ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: No , General . To tell you the truth , I take a pride in it . I cant help it .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Attention , Collins . Come here .Collins comes to himDo you see my uniform — all my medals ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: Yes , General . They strike the eye , as it were .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: They are meant to . Very well . Now you know , dont you , that your services to the community as a greengrocer are as important and as dignified as mine as a soldier ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: I 'm sure it 's very honorable of you to say so , General .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: emphaticallyYou know also , dont you , that any man who can see anything ridiculous , or unmanly , or unbecoming in your work or in your civic robes is not a gentleman , but a jumping , bounding , snorting cad ?

lg.l: Well , strictly between ourselves , that is my opinion ,
General .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Then why not dignify my niece 's wedding by wearing your robes ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: A bargain 's a bargain , General . Mrs Bridgenorth sent for the greengrocer , not for the alderman . It 's just as unpleasant to get more than you bargain for as to get less .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I 'm sure she will agree with me . I attach importance to this as an affirmation of solidarity in the service of the community . The Bishop 's apron , my uniform , your robes : the Church , the Army , and the Municipality .

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: retiringVery well , General .He turns dubiously to Lesbia on his way to the towerI wonder what my wife will say , Miss ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: What ! Is your , wife ashamed of your robes ?

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: No , sir , not ashamed of them . But she grudged the money for them ; and she will be afraid of my sleeves getting into the gravy . Mrs Bridgenorth , her placidity quite upset , comes in with a letter ; hurries past Collins ; and comes between Lesbia and the General .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Lesbia : Boxer : heres a pretty mess ! Collins goes out discreetly .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Whats the matter ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Reginald 's in London , and wants to come to the wedding .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: stupendedWell , dash my buttons !

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Oh , all right , let him come .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Let him come ! Why , the decree has not been made absolute yet . Is he to walk in here to Edith 's wedding , reeking from the Divorce Court ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: vexedly sitting down in the middle chairIt 's too bad . No : I cant forgive him , Lesbia , really . A man of Reginald 's age , with a young wife — the best of girls , and as pretty as she can be — to go off with a common woman from the streets ! Ugh !

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: You must make allowances . What can you expect ? Reginald was always weak . He was brought up to be weak . The family property was all mortgaged when he inherited it . He had to struggle along in constant money difficulties , hustled by his solicitors , morally bullied by the Barmecide , and physically bullied by Boxer , while they two were fighting their own way and getting well trained . You know very well he couldnt afford to marry until the mortgages were cleared and he was over fifty . And then of course he made a fool of himself marrying a child like Leo .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: But to hit her ! Absolutely to hit her ! He knocked her down — knocked her flat down on a flowerbed in the presence of his gardener . He ! the head of the family ! the man that stands before the Barmecide and myself as Bridgenorth of Bridgenorth ! to beat his wife and go off with a low woman and be divorced for it in the face of all England ! in the face of my uniform and Alfred 's apron ! I can never forget what I felt : it was only the King 's personal request — virtually a command — that stopped me from resigning my commission . I 'd cut Reginald dead if I met him in the street .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Besides , Leo 's coming . Theyd meet . It 's impossible , Lesbia .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Oh , I forgot that . That settles it . He mustnt come .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Of course he mustnt . You tell him that if he enters this house , I 'll leave it ; and so will every decent man and woman in it .

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: returning for a moment to announceMr Reginald , maam .He withdraws when Reginald enters

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: beside himselfWell , dash my buttons ! ! Reginald is just the man Lesbia has described . He is hardened and tough physically , and hasty and boyish in his manner and speech , belonging as he does to the large class of English gentlemen of propertysolicitor-managedwho have never developed intellectually since their schooldays . He is a muddled , rebellious , hasty , untidy , forgetful , always late sort of man , who very evidently needs the care of a capable woman , and has never been lucky or attractive enough to get it . All the same , a likeable man , from whom nobody apprehends any malice nor expects any achievement . In everything but years he is younger than his brother the General .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: coming forward between the General and Mrs BridgenorthAlice : it 's no use . I cant stay away from Edith 's wedding . Good morning , Lesbia . How are you , Boxer ?He offers the General his hand

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: with crushing stiffnessI was just telling Alice , sir , that if you entered this house , I should leave it .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Well , dont let me detain you , old chap . When you start calling people Sir , youre not particularly good company .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Dont you begin to quarrel . That wont improve the situation .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: I think you might have waited until you got my answer , Rejjy .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: It 's so jolly easy to say No in a letter . Wont you let me stay ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: How can I ? Leo 's coming .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Well , she wont mind .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Wont mind !!! !

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Dont talk nonsense , Rejjy ; and be off with you .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: with biting sarcasmAt school you lead a theory that women liked being knocked down , I remember .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Youre a nice , chivalrous , brotherly sort of swine , you are .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Mr Bridgenorth : are you going to leave this house or am I ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: You are , I hope .He emphasizes his intention to stay by sitting down

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Alice : will you allow me to be driven from Edith 's wedding by this —

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: warninglyBoxer !

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: — by this Respondent ? Is Edith to be given away by him ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Certainly not . Reginald : you were not asked to come ; and I have asked you to go . You know how fond I am of Leo ; and you know what she would feel if she came in and found you here .

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: again appearing in the towerMrs Reginald , maam .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: { No , no . Ask her to — }All three MRS BRIDGENORTH { Oh , how unfortunate ! } clamoring THE GENERAL { Well , dash my buttons ! } togetherIt is too late : Leo is already in the kitchen . Collins goes out , mutely abandoning a situation which he deplores but has been unable to save . Leo is very pretty , very youthful , very restless , and consequently very charming to people who are touched by youth and beauty , as well as to those who regard young women as more or less appetizing lollipops , and dont regard old women at all . Coldly studied , Leo 's restlessness is much less lovable than the kittenishness which comes from a rich and fresh vitality . She is a born fusser about herself and everybody else for whom she feels responsible ; and her vanity causes her to exaggerate her responsibilities officiously . All her fussing is about little things ; but she often calls them by big names , such as Art , the Divine Spark , the world , motherhood , good breeding , the Universe , the Creator , or anything else that happens to strike her imagination as sounding intellectually important . She has more than common imagination and no more than common conception and penetration ; so that she is always on the high horse about words and always in the perambulator about things . Considering herself clever , thoughtful , and superior to ordinary weaknesses and prejudices , she recklessly attaches herself to clever men on that understanding , with the result that they are first delighted , then exasperated , and finally bored . When marrying Reginald she told her friends that there was a great deal in him which needed bringing out . If she were a middle-aged man she would be the terror of his club . Being a pretty young woman , she is forgiven everything , proving that “ Tout comprendre , c'est tout pardonner ” is an error , the fact being that the secret of forgiving everything is to understand nothing . She runs in fussily , full of her own importance , and swoops on Lesbia , who is much less disposed to spoil her than Mrs Bridgenorth is . But Leo affects a special intimacy with Lesbia , as of two thinkers among the Philistines .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: to Lesbia , kissing herGood morning .Coming to Mrs BridgenorthHow do , Alice ?Passing on towards the hearthWhy so gloomy , General ?Reginald rises between her and the GeneralOh , Rejjy ! What will the King 's Proctor say ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Damn the King 's Proctor !

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Naughty . Well , I suppose I must kiss you ; but dont any of you tell .She kisses him . They can hardly believe their eyesHave you kept all your promises ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Oh , dont begin bothering about those —

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: insistingHave ? You ? Kept ? Your ? Promises ? Have you rubbed your head with the lotion every night ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Yes , yes . Nearly every night .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Nearly ! I know what that means . Have you worn your liver pad ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: solemnlyLeo : forgiveness is one of the most beautiful traits in a woman 's nature ; but there are things that should not be forgiven to a man . When a man knocks a woman downLeo gives a little shriek of laughter and collapses on a chair next Mrs Bridgenorth , on her left

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: sardonicallyThe man that would raise his hand to a woman , save in the way of a kindness , is unworthy the name of Bridgenorth .He sits down at the end of the table nearest the hearth

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: much huffedOh , well , if Leo does not mind , of course I have no more to say . But I think you might , out of consideration for the family , beat your wife in private and not in the presence of the gardener .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: out of patienceWhats the good of beating your wife unless theres a witness to prove it afterwards ? You dont suppose a man beats his wife for the fun of it , do you ? How could she have got her divorce if I hadnt beaten her ? Nice state of things , that !

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: gaspingDo you mean to tell me that you did it in cold blood ? simply to get rid of your wife ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: No , I did n't : I did it to get her rid of me . What would you do if you were fool enough to marry a woman thirty years younger than yourself , and then found that she didnt care for you , and was in love with a young fellow with a face like a mushroom .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: He has not .Bursting into tearsAnd you are most unkind to say I didnt care for you . Nobody could have been fonder of you .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: A nice way of shewing your fondness ! I had to go out and dig that flower bed all over with my own hands to soften it . I had to pick all the stones out of it . And then she complained that I hadnt done it properly , because she got a worm down her neck . I had to go to Brighton with a poor creature who took a fancy to me on the way down , and got conscientious scruples about committing perjury after dinner . I had to put her down in the hotel book as Mrs Reginald Bridgenorth : Leo 's name ! Do you know what that feels like to a decent man ? Do you know what a decent man feels about his wife 's name ? How would you like to go into a hotel before all the waiters and people with — with that on your arm ? Not that it was the poor girl 's fault , of course ; only she started crying because I couldnt stand her touching me ; and now she keeps writing to me . And then I 'm held up in the public court for cruelty and adultery , and turned away from Edith 's wedding by Alice , and lectured by you ! a bachelor , and a precious green one at that . What do you know about it ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Am I to understand that the whole case was one of collusion ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Of course it was . Half the cases are collusions : what are people to do ?The General , passing his hand dazedly over his bewildered brow , sinks into the railed chairAnd what do you take me for , that you should have the cheek to pretend to believe all that rot about my knocking Leo about and leaving her for — for a — a — Ugh ! you should have seen her .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: This is perfectly astonishing to me . Why did you do it ? Why did Leo allow it ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Youd better ask her .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: still in tearsI 'm sure I never thought it would be so horrid for Rejjy . I offered honorably to do it myself , and let him divorce me ; but he wouldnt . And he said himself that it was the only way to do it — that it was the law that he should do it that way . I never saw that hateful creature until that day in Court . If he had only shewn her to me before , I should never have allowed it .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: You did all this for Leo 's sake , Rejjy ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: with an unbearable sense of injuryI shouldnt mind a bit if it were for Leo 's sake . But to have to do it to make room for that mushroom-faced serpent —!

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: jumping upWhat right had he to be made room for ? Are you in your senses ? What right ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: The right of being a young man , suitable to a young woman . I had no right at my age to marry Leo : she knew no more about life than a child .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: I knew a great deal more about it than a great baby like you . I 'm sure I dont know how youll get on with no one to take care of you : I often lie awake at night thinking about it . And now youve made me thoroughly miserable .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Serve you right !She weepsThere : dont get into a tantrum , Leo .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: May one ask who is the mushroom-faced serpent ?

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: He isnt .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Sinjon Hotchkiss , of course .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Sinjon Hotchkiss ! Why , he 's coming to the wedding !

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: What ! In that case I 'm offhe makes for the tower

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: } {seizing himNo you shant . You promised to be nice toall four him . THE GENERAL } rushing { No , dont go , old chap . Not after him from Edith 's wedding . and capturing him on the MRS. BRIDGE - thresholdNORTH } { Oh , do stay , Benjjy . I shall really be hurt if you desert us . LESBIA } { Better stay , Reginald . You must meet him sooner or later .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: A moment ago , when I wanted to stay , you were all shoving me out of the house . Now that I want to go , you wont let me .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: I shall send a note to Mr Hotchkiss not to come .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: weeping againOh , Alice !She comes back to her chair , heartbroken

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: out of patienceOh well , let her have her way . Let her have her mushroom . Let him come . Let them all come . He crosses the kitchen to the oak chest and sits sulkily on it . Mrs Bridgenorth shrugs her shoulders and sits at the table in Reginald 's neighborhood listening in placid helplessness . Lesbia , out of patience with Leo 's tears , goes into the garden and sits there near the door , snuffing up the open air in her relief from the domestic stuffness of Reginald 's affairs .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: It 's so cruel of you to go on pretending that I dont care for you , Rejjy .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: bitterlyShe explained to me that it was only that she had exhausted my conversation .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: coming paternally to LeoMy dear girl : all the conversation in the world has been exhausted long ago . Heaven knows I have exhausted the conversation of the British Army these thirty years ; but I dont leave it on that account .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: It 's not that Ive exhausted it ; but he will keep on repeating it when I want to read or go to sleep . And Sinjon amuses me . He 's so clever .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: stungHa ! The old complaint . You all want geniuses to marry . This demand for clever men is ridiculous . Somebody must marry the plain , honest , stupid fellows . Have you thought of that ?

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: But there are such lots of stupid women to marry . Why do they want to marry us ? Besides , Rejjy knows that I 'm quite fond of him . I like him because he wants me ; and I like Sinjon because I want him . I feel that I have a duty to Rejjy .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Precisely : you have .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: And , of course , Sinjon has the same duty to me .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Tut , tut !

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Oh , how silly the law is ! Why cant I marry them both ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: shockedLeo !

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Well , I love them both . I should like to marry a lot of men . I should like to have Rejjy for every day , and Sinjon for concerts and theatres and going out in the evenings , and some great austere saint for about once a year at the end of the season , and some perfectly blithering idiot of a boy to be quite wicked with . I so seldom feel wicked ; and , when I do , it 's such a pity to waste it merely because it 's too silly to confess to a real grown-up man .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: This is the kind of thing , you knowHelplesslyWell , there it is !

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: decisivelyAlice : this is a job for the Barmecide . He 's a Bishop : it 's his duty to talk to Leo . I can stand a good deal ; but when it comes to flat polygamy and polyandry , we ought to do something .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: going to the study doorDo come here a moment , Alfred . We 're in a difficulty .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: withinAsk Collins , I 'm busy .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Collins wont do . It 's something very serious . Do come just a moment , dear .When she hears him coming she takes a chair at the nearest end of the tableThe Bishop comes out of his study . He is still a slim active man , spare of flesh , and younger by temperament than his brothers . He has a delicate skin , fine hands , a salient nose with chin to match , a short beard which accentuates his sharp chin by bristling forward , clever humorous eyes , not without a glint of mischief in them , ready bright speech , and the ways of a successful man who is always interested in himself and generally rather well pleased with himself . When Lesbia hears his voice she turns her chair towards him , and presently rises and stands in the doorway listening to the conversation .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: going to LeoGood morning , my dear . Hullo ! Youve brought Reginald with you . Thats very nice of you . Have you reconciled them , Boxer ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Reconciled them ! Why , man , the whole divorce was a put-up job . She wants to marry some fellow named Hotchkiss .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: A fellow with a face like —

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: You shant , Rejjy . He has a very fine face .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: And now she says she wants to marry both of them , and a lot of other people as well .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: I didnt say I wanted to marry them : I only said I should like to marry them .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Quite a nice distinction , Leo .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Just occasionally , you know .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: sitting down cosily beside herQuite so . Sometimes a poet , sometimes a Bishop , sometimes a fairy prince , sometimes somebody quite indescribable , and sometimes nobody at all .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Yes : thats just it . How did you know ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Oh , I should say most imaginative and cultivated young women feel like that . I wouldnt give a rap for one who didnt . Shakespear pointed out long ago that a woman wanted a Sunday husband as well as a weekday one . But , as usual , he didnt follow up the idea .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: aghastAm I to understand —

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: cutting him shortNow , Boxer , am I the Bishop or are you ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: sulkilyYou .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Then dont ask me are you to understand . “ Yours not to reason why : yours but to do and die ” —

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Oh , very well : go on . I 'm not clever . Only a silly soldier man . Ha ! Go on .He throws himself into the railed chair , as one prepared for the worst

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Alfred : dont tease Boxer .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: If we are going to discuss ethical questions we must begin by giving the devil fair play . Boxer never does . England never does . We always assume that the devil is guilty ; and we wont allow him to prove his innocence , because it would be against public morals if he succeeded . We used to do the same with prisoners accused of high treason . And the consequence is that we overreach ourselves ; and the devil gets the better of us after all . Perhaps thats what most of us intend him to do .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Alfred : we asked you here to preach to Leo . You are preaching at me instead . I am not conscious of having said or done anything that calls for that unsolicited attention .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: But poor little Leo has only told the simple truth ; whilst you , Boxer , are striking moral attitudes .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I suppose thats an epigram . I dont understand epigrams . I 'm only a silly soldier man . Ha ! But I can put a plain question . Is Leo to be encouraged to be a polygamist ?

lg.l: Remember the British Empire , Boxer . Youre a British
General , you know .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: What has that to do with polygamy ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Well , the great majority of our fellow-subjects are polygamists . I cant as a British Bishop insult them by speaking disrespectfully of polygamy . It 's a very interesting question . Many very interesting men have been polygamists : Solomon , Mahomet , and our friend the Duke of — of — hm ! I never can remember his name .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: It would become you better , Alfred , to send that silly girl back to her husband and her duty than to talk clever and mock at your religion . “ What God hath joined together let no man put asunder . ” Remember that .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Dont be afraid , Boxer . What God hath joined together no man ever shall put asunder : God will take care of that .To LeoBy the way , who was it that joined you and Reginald , my dear ?

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: It was that awful little curate that afterwards drank , and travelled first class with a third-class ticket , and then tried to go on the stage . But they wouldnt have him . He called himself Egerton Fotheringay .

lg.l: Well , whom Egerton Fotheringay hath joined , let Sir
Gorell Barnes put asunder by all means .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I may be a silly soldier man ; but I call this blasphemy .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: gravelyBetter for me to take the name of Mr Egerton Fotheringay in earnest than for you to take a higher name in vain .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Cant you three brothers ever meet without quarrelling ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: mildlyThis is not quarrelling , Lesbia : it 's only English family life . Good morning .

lg.l: You know , Bishop , it 's very dear of you to take my part ; but
I 'm not sure that I 'm not a little shocked .
Then I think Ive been a little more successful than
Boxer in getting you into a proper frame of mind .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: snortingHa !

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Not a bit ; for now I 'm going to shock you worse than ever . I think Solomon was an old beast .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Precisely what you ought to think of him , my dear . Dont apologize .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: more shockedWell , but hang it ! Solomon was in the Bible . And , after all , Solomon was Solomon .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: And I stick to it : I still want to have a lot of interesting men to know quite intimately — to say everything I think of to them , and have them say everything they think of to me .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: So you shall , my dear , if you are lucky . But you know you neednt marry them all . Think of all the buttons you would have to sew on . Besides , nothing is more dreadful than a husband who keeps telling you everything he thinks , and always wants to know what you think .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: struck by thisWell , thats very true of Rejjy : In fact , thats why I had to divorce him .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: condolingYes : he repeats himself dreadfully , doesnt he ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Look here , Alfred . If I have my faults , let her find them out for herself without your help .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: She has found them all out already , Reginald .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: a little huffilyAfter all , there are worse men than Reginald . I daresay he 's not so clever as you ; but still he 's not such a fool as you seem to think him !

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Quite right , dear : stand up for your husband . I hope you will always stand up for all your husbands .He rises and goes to the hearth , where he stands complacently with his back to the fireplace , beaming at them all as at a roomful of children

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Please dont talk as if I wanted to marry a whole regiment . For me there can never be more than two . I shall never love anybody but Rejjy and Sinjon .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: A man with a face like a —

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: I wont have it , Rejjy . It 's disgusting .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: You see , my dear , youll exhaust Sinjon 's conversation too in a week or so . A man is like a phonograph with half-a-dozen records . You soon get tired of them all ; and yet you have to sit at table whilst he reels them off to every new visitor . In the end you have to be content with his common humanity ; and when you come down to that , you find out about men what a great English poet of my acquaintance used to say about women : that they all taste alike . Marry whom you please : at the end of a month he 'll be Reginald over again . It wasnt worth changing : indeed it wasnt .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Then it 's a mistake to get married .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: It is , my dear ; but it 's a much bigger mistake not to get married .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: risingHa ! You hear that , Lesbia ?He joins her at the garden door

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Thats only an epigram , Boxer .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Sound sense , Lesbia . When a man talks rot , thats epigram : when he talks sense , then I agree with him .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: coming off the oak chest and looking at his watchIt 's getting late . Wheres Edith ? Hasnt she got into her veil and orange blossoms yet ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Do go and hurry her , Lesbia .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: going out through the towerCome with me , Leo .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: following Lesbia outYes , certainly . The Bishop goes over to his wife and sits down , taking her hand and kissing it by way of beginning a conversation with her .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Alice : Ive had another letter from the mysterious lady who cant spell . I like that woman 's letters . Theres an intensity of passion in them that fascinates me .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Do you mean Incognita Appassionata ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: turning abruptly ; he has been looking out into the gardenDo you mean to say that women write love-letters to you ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: They never do to me .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: The army doesnt attract women : the Church does .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Do you consider it right to let them ? They may be married women , you know .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: They always are . This one is .To Mrs BridgenorthDont you think her letters are quite the best love-letters I get ?To the two menPoor Alice has to read my love-letters aloud to me at breakfast , when theyre worth it .

lg.l: There really is something fascinating about
Incognita . She never gives her address . Thats a good sign .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Mf ! No assignations , you mean ?

sp.speaker: THE B
sp.p: ishop . Oh yes : she began the correspondence by making a very curious but very natural assignation . She wants me to meet her in heaven . I hope I shall .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Well , I must say I hope not , Alfred . I hope not .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: She says she is happily married , and that love is a necessary of life to her , but that she must have , high above all her lovers —

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: She has several apparently —

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: — some great man who will never know her , never touch her , as she is on earth , but whom she can meet in Heaven when she has risen above all the everyday vulgarities of earthly love .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: risingExcellent . Very good for her ; and no trouble to me . Everybody ought to have one of these idealizations , like Dante 's Beatrice .He clasps his hands behind him , and strolls to the hearth and back , singingLesbia appears in the tower , rather perturbed .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Alice : will you come upstairs ? Edith is not dressed .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: risingNot dressed ! Does she know what hour it is ?

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: She has locked herself into her room , reading . The Bishop 's song ceases ; he stops dead in his stroll .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Reading !

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: What is she reading ?

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Some pamphlet that came by the eleven o'clock post . She wont come out . She wont open the door . And she says she doesnt know whether she 's going to be married or not till she 's finished the pamphlet . Did you ever hear such a thing ? Do come and speak to her .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Alfred : you had better go .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Try Collins .

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: Weve tried Collins already . He got all that Ive told you out of her through the keyhole . Come , Alice .She vanishes . Mrs Bridgenorth hurries after her

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: This means a delay . I shall go back to my workhe makes for the study door

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: What are you working at now ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: stoppingA chapter in my history of marriage . I 'm just at the Roman business , you know .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: coming from the garden door to the chair Mrs Bridgenorth has just left , and sitting downNot more Ritualism , I hope , Alfred ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Oh no . I mean ancient Rome .He seats himself on the edge of the tableIve just come to the period when the propertied classes refused to get married and went in for marriage settlements instead . A few of the oldest families stuck to the marriage tradition so as to keep up the supply of vestal virgins , who had to be legitimate ; but nobody else dreamt of getting married . It 's all very interesting , because we 're coming to that here in England ; except that as we dont require any vestal virgins , nobody will get married at all , except the poor , perhaps .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: You take it devilishly coolly . Reginald : do you think the Barmecide 's quite sane ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: No worse than ever he was .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: to the BishopDo you mean to say you believe such a thing will ever happen in England as that respectable people will give up being married ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: In England especially they will . In other countries the introduction of reasonable divorce laws will save the situation ; but in England we always let an institution strain itself until it breaks . Ive told our last four Prime Ministers that if they didnt make our marriage laws reasonable there would be a strike against marriage , and that it would begin among the propertied classes , where no Government would dare to interfere with it .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: What did they say to that ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: The usual thing . Quite agreed with me , but were sure that they were the only sensible men in the world , and that the least hint of marriage reform would lose them the next election . And then lost it all the same : on cordite , on drink , on Chinese labor in South Africa , on all sorts of trumpery .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: lurching across the kitchen towards the hearth with his hands in his pocketsIt 's no use : they wont listen to our sort .Turning on themOf course they have to make you a Bishop and Boxer a General , because , after all , their blessed rabble of snobs and cads and half-starved shopkeepers cant do government work ; and the bounders and week-enders are too lazy and vulgar . Theyd simply rot without us ; but what do they ever do for us ? what attention do they ever pay to what we say and what we want ? I take it that we Bridgenorths are a pretty typical English family of the sort that has always set things straight and stuck up for the right to think and believe according to our conscience . But nowadays we are expected to dress and eat as the week-end bounders do , and to think and believe as the converted cannibals of Central Africa do , and to lie down and let every snob and every cad and every halfpenny journalist walk over us . Why , theres not a newspaper in England today that represents what I call solid Bridgenorth opinion and tradition . Half of them read as if they were published at the nearest mother 's meeting , and the other half at the nearest motor garage . Do you call these chaps gentlemen ? Do you call them Englishmen ? I dont .He throws himself disgustedly into the nearest chair

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: excited by Reginald 's eloquenceDo you see my uniform ? What did Collins say ? It strikes the eye . It was meant to . I put it on expressly to give the modern army bounder a smack in the eye . Somebody has to set a right example by beginning . Well , let it be a Bridgenorth . I believe in family blood and tradition , by George .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: musingI wonder who will begin the stand against marriage . It must come some day . I was married myself before I 'd thought about it ; and even if I had thought about it I was too much in love with Alice to let anything stand in the way . But , you know , Ive seen one of our daughters after another — Ethel , Jane , Fanny , and Christina and Florence — go out at that door in their veils and orange blossoms ; and Ive always wondered whether theyd have gone quietly if theyd known what they were doing . Ive a horrible misgiving about that pamphlet . All progress means war with Society . Heaven forbid that Edith should be one of the combatants ! St John Hotchkiss comes into the tower ushered by Collins . He is a very smart young gentleman of twenty-nine or thereabouts , correct in dress to the last thread of his collar , but too much preoccupied with his ideas to be embarrassed by any concern as to his appearance . He talks about himself with energetic gaiety . He talks to other people with a sweet forbearanceimplying a kindly consideration for their stupiditywhich infuriates those whom he does not succeed in amusing . They either lose their tempers with him or try in vain to snub him .

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: announcingMr Hotchkiss .He withdraws

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: clapping Reginald gaily on the shoulder as he passes himTootle loo , Rejjy .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: curtly , without rising or turning his headMorning .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Good morning , Bishop .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: coming off the tableWhat on earth are you doing here , Sinjon ? You belong to the bridegroom 's party : youve no business here until after the ceremony .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Yes , I know : thats just it . May I have a word with you in private ? Rejjy or any of the family wont matter ; but —he glances at the General , who has risen rather stiffly , as he strongly disapproves of the part played by Hotchkiss in Reginald 's domestic affairs

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: All right , Sinjon . This is our brother , General Bridgenorth .He goes to the hearth and posts himself there , with his hands clasped behind him

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Oh , good !He turns to the General , and takes out a card-caseAs you are in the service , allow me to introduce myself . Read my card , please .He presents his card to the astonished General

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: reading“ Mr St John Hotchkiss , the Celebrated Coward , late Lieutenant in the 165th Fusiliers . ”

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: with a chuckleHe was sent back from South Africa because he funked an order to attack , and spoiled his commanding officer 's plan .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: very gravelyI remember the case now . I had forgotten the name . I 'll not refuse your acquaintance , Mr Hotchkiss ; partly because youre my brother 's guest , and partly because Ive seen too much active service not to know that every man 's nerve plays him false at one time or another , and that some very honorable men should never go into action at all , because theyre not built that way . But if I were you I should not use that visiting card . No doubt it 's an honorable trait in your character that you dont wish any man to give you his hand in ignorance of your disgrace ; but you had better allow us to forget . We wish to forget . It isnt your disgrace alone : it 's a disgrace to the army and to all of us . Pardon my plain speaking .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: sunnilyMy dear General , I dont know what fear means in the military sense of the word . Ive fought seven duels with the sabre in Italy and Austria , and one with pistols in France , without turning a hair . There was no other way in which I could vindicate my motives in refusing to make that attack at Smutsfontein . I dont pretend to be a brave man . I 'm afraid of wasps . I 'm afraid of cats . In spite of the voice of reason , I 'm afraid of ghosts ; and twice Ive fled across Europe from false alarms of cholera . But afraid to fight I am not .He turns gaily to Reginald and slaps him on the shoulderEh , Rejjy ?Reginald grunts

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Then why did you not do your duty at Smutsfontein ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: I did my duty — my higher duty . If I had made that attack , my commanding officer 's plan would have been successful , and he would have been promoted . Now I happen to think that the British Army should be commanded by gentlemen , and by gentlemen alone . This man was not a gentleman . I sacrificed my military career — I faced disgrace and social ostracism rather than give that man his chance .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: generously indignantYour commanding officer , sir , was my friend Major Billiter .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Precisely . What a name !

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: And pray , sir , on what ground do you dare allege that Major Billiter is not a gentleman ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: By an infallible sign : one of those trifles that stamp a man . He eats rice pudding with a spoon .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: very angryConfound you , I eat rice pudding with a spoon . Now !

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Oh , so do I , frequently . But there are ways of doing these things . Billiter 's way was unmistakable .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Well , I 'll tell you something now . When I thought you were only a coward , I pitied you , and would have done what I could to help you back to your place in Society —

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: interrupting himThank you : I havnt lost it . My motives have been fully appreciated . I was made an honorary member of two of the smartest clubs in London when the truth came out .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Well , sir , those clubs consist of snobs ; and you are a jumping , bounding , prancing , snorting snob yourself .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: amused , but hospitably remonstrantMy dear Boxer !

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: delightedHow kind of you to say so , General ! Youre quite right : I am a snob . Why not ? The whole strength of England lies in the fact that the enormous majority of the English people are snobs . They insult poverty . They despise vulgarity . They love nobility . They admire exclusiveness . They will not obey a man risen from the ranks . They never trust one of their own class . I agree with them . I share their instincts . In my undergraduate days I was a Republican-a Socialist . I tried hard to feel toward a common man as I do towards a duke . I couldnt . Neither can you . Well , why should we be ashamed of this aspiration towards what is above us ? Why dont I say that an honest man 's the noblest work of God ? Because I dont think so . If he 's not a gentleman , I dont care whether he 's honest or not : I shouldnt let his son marry my daughter . And thats the test , mind . Thats the test . You feel as I do . You are a snob in fact : I am a snob , not only in fact , but on principle . I shall go down in history , not as the first snob , but as the first avowed champion of English snobbery , and its first martyr in the army . The navy boasts two such martyrs in Captains Kirby and Wade , who were shot for refusing to fight under Admiral Benbow , a promoted cabin boy . I have always envied them their glory .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: As a British General , Sir , I have to inform you that if any officer under my command violated the sacred equality of our profession by putting a single jot of his duty or his risk on the shoulders of the humblest drummer boy , I 'd shoot him with my own hand .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: That sentiment is not your equality , General , but your superiority . Ask the Bishop .He seats himself on the edge of the table

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: I cant support you , Sinjon . My profession also compels me to turn my back on snobbery . You see , I have to do such a terribly democratic thing to every child that is brought to me . Without distinction of class I have to confer on it a rank so high and awful that all the grades in Debrett and Burke seem like the medals they give children in Infant Schools in comparison . I 'm not allowed to make any class distinction . They are all soldiers and servants , not officers and masters .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Ah , youre quoting the Baptism service . Thats not a bit real , you know . If I may say so , you would both feel so much more at peace with yourselves if you would acknowledge and confess your real convictions . You know you dont really think a Bishop the equal of a curate , or a lieutenant in a line regiment the equal of a general .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Of course I do . I was a curate myself .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: And I was a lieutenant in a line regiment .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: And I was nothing . But we 're all our own and one another 's equals , arnt we ? So perhaps when youve quite done talking about yourselves , we shall get to whatever business Sinjon came about .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: coming off the table hastilymy dear fellow . I beg a thousand pardons . Oh ! true , It 's about the wedding ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: What about the wedding ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Well , we cant get our man up to the scratch . Cecil has locked himself in his room and wont see or speak to any one . I went up to his room and banged at the door . I told him I should look through the keyhole if he didnt answer . I looked through the keyhole . He was sitting on his bed , reading a book .Reginald rises in consternation . The General recoilsI told him not to be an ass , and so forth . He said he was not going to budge until he had finished the book . I asked him did he know what time it was , and whether he happened to recollect that he had a rather important appointment to marry Edith . He said the sooner I stopped interrupting him , the sooner he 'd be ready . Then he stuffed his fingers in his ears ; turned over on his elbows ; and buried himself in his beastly book . I couldnt get another word out of him ; so I thought I 'd better come here and warn you .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: This looks to me like theyve arranged it between them .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: No . Edith has no sense of humor . And Ive never seen a man in a jocular mood on his wedding morning . Collins appears in the tower , ushering in the bridegroom , a young gentleman with good looks of the serious kind , somewhat careworn by an exacting conscience , and just now distracted by insoluble problems of conduct .

sp.speaker: COLLINS
sp.p: announcingMr Cecil Sykes .He retires

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Look here , Cecil : this is all wrong . Youve no business here until after the wedding . Hang it , man ! youre the bridegroom .

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: coming to the Bishop , and addressing him with dogged desperationIve come here to say this . When I proposed to Edith I was in utter ignorance of what I was letting myself in for legally . Having given my word , I will stand to it . You have me at your mercy : marry me if you insist . But take notice that I protest .He sits down distractedly in the railed chair

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: { both } What the devil do you mean by { highly } This ? What the — REGINALD { incensed } Confound your impertinence , what do you —

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: { } Easy , Rejjy . Easy , old man . Steady , steady . { }Reginald subsides into his chair . Hotchkiss { } sits on his right , appeasing him .THE BISHOP { } No , please , Rej . Control yourself , Boxer , I beg you .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: I tell you I cant control myself . Ive been controlling myself for the last half-hour until I feel like bursting .He sits down furiously at the end of the table next the study

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: pointing to the simmering Reginald and the boiling GeneralThats just it , Bishop . Edith is her uncle 's niece . She cant control herself any more than they can . And she 's a Bishop 's daughter . That means that she 's engaged in social work of all sorts : organizing shop assistants and sweated work girls and all that . When her blood boils about itand it boils at least once a weekshe doesnt care what she says .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Well : you knew that when you proposed to her .

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: Yes ; but I didnt know that when we were married I should be legally responsible if she libelled anybody , though all her property is protected against me as if I were the lowest thief and cadger . This morning somebody sent me Belfort Bax 's essays on Men 's Wrongs ; and they have been a perfect eye-opener to me . Bishop : I 'm not thinking of myself : I would face anything for Edith . But my mother and sisters are wholly dependent on my property . I 'd rather have to cut off an inch from my right arm than a hundred a year from my mother 's income . I owe everything to her care of me . Edith , in dressing-jacket and petticoat , comes in through the tower , swiftly and determinedly , pamphlet in hand , principles up in arms , more of a bishop than her father , yet as much a gentlewoman as her mother . She is the typical spoilt child of a clerical household : almost as terrible a product as the typical spoilt child of a Bohemian household : that is , all her childish affectations of conscientious scruple and religious impulse have been applauded and deferred to until she has become an ethical snob of the first water . Her father 's sense of humor and her mother 's placid balance have done something to save her humanity ; but her impetuous temper and energetic will , unrestrained by any touch of humor or scepticism , carry everything before them . Imperious and dogmatic , she takes command of the party at once .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: standing behind Cecil 's chairCecil : I heard your voice . I must speak to you very particularly . Papa : go away . Go away everybody .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: crossing to the study doorI think there can be no doubt that Edith wishes us to retire . Come .He stands in the doorway , waiting for them to follow

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: Thats it , you see . It 's just this outspokenness that makes my position hard , much as I admire her for it .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Do you want me to flatter and be untruthful ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: No , not exactly that .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Does anybody want me to flatter and be untruthful ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Well , since you ask me , I do . Surely it 's the very first qualification for tolerable social intercourse .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: markedlyI hope you will always tell ME the truth , my darling , at all events .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: complacently coming to the fireplaceYou can depend on me for that , Uncle Boxer .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Are you sure you have any adequate idea of what the truth about a military man really is ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: aggressivelyWhats the truth about you , I wonder ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Oh , quite unfit for publication in its entirety . If Miss Bridgenorth begins telling it , I shall have to leave the room .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: I 'm not at all surprised to hear it .RisingBut whats it got to do with our business here to-day ? Is it you thats going to be married or is it Edith ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: I 'm so sorry , I get so interested in myself that I thrust myself into the front of every discussion in the most insufferable way .Reginald , with an exclamation of disgust , crosses the kitchen towards the study doorBut , my dear Rejjy , are you quite sure that Miss Bridgenorth is going to be married ? Are you , Miss Bridgenorth ? Before Edith has time to answer her mother returns with Leo and Lesbia .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Yes , here she is , of course . I told you I heard her dash downstairs .She comes to the end of the table next the fireplace

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: transfixed in the middle of the kitchenAnd Cecil ! !

sp.speaker: LESBIA
sp.p: And Sinjon !

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Edith wishes to speak to Cecil .Mrs Bridgenorth comes to him . Lesbia goes into the garden , as beforeLet us go into my study .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: But she must come and dress . Look at the hour !

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Come , Leo dear .Leo follows her reluctantly . They are about to go into the study with the Bishop

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Do you know , Miss Bridgenorth , I should most awfully like to hear what you have to say to poor Cecil .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: scandalizedWell !

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Who is poor Cecil , pray ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: One always calls a man that on his wedding morning : I dont know why . I 'm his best man , you know . Dont you think it gives me a certain right to be present in Cecil 's interest ?

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: gravelyThere is such a thing as delicacy , Mr Hotchkiss .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: There is such a thing as curiosity , General .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: furiousDelicacy is thrown away here , Alfred . Edith : you had better take Sykes into the study . The group at the study door breaks up . The General flings himself into the last chair on the long side of the table , near the garden door . Leo sits at the end , next him , and Mrs Bridgenorth next Leo . Reginald returns to the oak chest , to be near Leo ; and the Bishop goes to his wife and stands by her .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: to EdithOf course I 'll go if you wish me to . But Cecil 's objection to go through with it was so entirely on public grounds —

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: with quick suspicionHis objection ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: Sinjon : you have no right to say that . I expressly said that I 'm ready to go through with it .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Cecil : do you mean to say that you have been raising difficulties about our marriage ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: I raise no difficulty . But I do beg you to be careful what you say about people . You must remember , my dear , that when we are married I shall be responsible for everything you say . Only last week you said on a public platform that Slattox and Chinnery were scoundrels . They could have got a thousand pounds damages apiece from me for that if we 'd been married at the time .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: austerelyI never said anything of the sort . I never stoop to mere vituperation : what would my girls say of me if I did ? I chose my words most carefully . I said they were tyrants , liars , and thieves ; and so they are . Slattox is even worse .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: I 'm afraid that would be at least five thousand pounds .

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: If it were only myself , I shouldnt care . But my mother and sisters ! Ive no right to sacrifice them .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: You neednt be alarmed . I 'm not going to be married .

sp.speaker: ALL THE REST
sp.p: Not !

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: in consternationEdith ! Are you throwing me over ?

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: How can I ? you have been beforehand with me .

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: On my honor , no . All I said was that I didnt know the law when I asked you to be my wife .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: And you wouldnt have asked me if you had . Is that it ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: No . I should have asked you for my sake be a little more careful — not to ruin me uselessly .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: You think the truth useless ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Much worse than useless , I assure you . Frequently most mischievous .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Sinjon : hold your tongue . You are a chatterbox and a fool !

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: }shocked{ Edith ! THE BISHOP } { My love !

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: mildlyI shall not take an action , Cecil .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: to HotchkissSorry ; but you are old enough to know better .To the othersAnd now since there is to be no wedding , we had better get back to our work . Mamma : will you tell Collins to cut up the wedding cake into thirty-three pieces for the club girls ? My not being married is no reason why they should be disappointed .She turns to go

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: gallantlyIf youll allow me to take Cecil 's place , Miss Bridgenorth —

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Sinjon !

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Oh , I forgot . I beg your pardon .To Edith , apologeticallyA prior engagement .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: What ! You and Leo ! I thought so . Well , hadnt you two better get married at once ? I dont approve of long engagements . The breakfast 's ready : the cake 's ready : everything 's ready . I 'll lend Leo my veil and things .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: I 'm afraid they must wait until the decree is made absolute , my dear . And the license is not transferable .

lg.l: Oh well , it cant be helped . Is there anything else before
I go off to the Club ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: You dont seem much disappointed , Edith . I cant help saying that much .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: And you cant help looking enormously relieved , Cecil . We shant be any worse friends , shall we ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: distractedlyOf course not . Still — I 'm perfectly ready — at least — if it were not for my mother — Oh , I dont know what to do . Ive been so fond of you ; and when the worry of the wedding was over I should have been so fond of you again —

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: petting himCome , come ! dont make a scene , dear . Youre quite right . I dont think a woman doing public work ought to get married unless her husband feels about it as she does . I dont blame you at all for throwing me over .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: bouncing off the chest , and passing behind the General to the other end of the tableNo : dash it ! I 'm not going to stand this . Why is the man always to be put in the wrong ? Be honest , Edith . Why werent you dressed ? Were you going to throw him over ? If you were , take your fair share of the blame ; and dont put it all on him .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: sweetlyWould it not be better —

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: violentlyNow look here , Hotchkiss . Who asked you to cut in ? Is your name Edith ? Am I your uncle ?

lg.l: I wish you were : I should like to have an uncle ,
Reginald .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Yah ! Sykes : are you ready to marry Edith or are you not ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: Ive already said that I 'm quite ready . A promise is a promise .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: We dont want to know whether a promise is a promise or not . Cant you answer yes or no without spoiling it and setting Hotchkiss here grinning like a Cheshire cat ? If she puts on her veil and goes to Church , will you marry her ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: Certainly . Yes .

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: Thats all right . Now , Edie , put on your veil and off with you to the church . The bridegroom 's waiting .He sits down at the table

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Is it understood that Slattox and Chinnery are liars and thieves , and that I hope by next Wednesday to have in my hands conclusive evidence that Slattox is something much worse ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: I made no conditions as to that when I proposed to you ; and now I cant go back . I hope Providence will spare my poor mother . I say again I 'm ready to marry you .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Then I think you shew great weakness of character ; and instead of taking advantage of it I shall set you a better example . I want to know is this true .She produces a pamphlet and takes it to the Bishop ; then sits down between Hotchkiss and her mother

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: reading the titleDo YOU KNOW WHAT YOU ARE GOING TO DO ? BY A WOMAN WHO HAS DONE IT . May I ask , my dear , what she did ?

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: She got married . When she had three children — the eldest only four years old — her husband committed a murder , and then attempted to commit suicide , but only succeeded in disfiguring himself . Instead of hanging him , they sent him to penal servitude for life , for the sake , they said , of his wife and infant children . And she could not get a divorce from that horrible murderer . They would not even keep him imprisoned for life . For twenty years she had to live singly , bringing up her children by her own work , and knowing that just when they were grown up and beginning life , this dreadful creature would be let out to disgrace them all , and prevent the two girls getting decently married , and drive the son out of the country perhaps . Is that really the law ? Am I to understand that if Cecil commits a mur - der , or forges , or steals , or becomes an atheist , I cant get divorced from him ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Yes , my dear . That is so . You must take him for better for worse .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: Then I most certainly refuse to enter into any such wicked contract . What sort of servants ? what sort of friends ? what sort of Prime Ministers should we have if we took them for better for worse for all their lives ? We should simply encourage them in every sort of wickedness . Surely my husband 's conduct is of more importance to me than Mr Balfour 's or Mr Asquith 's . If I had known the law I would never have consented . I dont believe any woman would if she realized what she was doing .

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: But I 'm not going to commit murder .

sp.speaker: EDITH
sp.p: How do you know ? Ive sometimes wanted to murder Slattox . Have you never wanted to murder somebody , Uncle Rejjy ?

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: at Hotchkiss , with intense expressionYes .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: Rejjy !

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: I said yes ; and I mean yes . There was one night , Hotchkiss , when I jolly near shot you and Leo and finished up with myself ; and thats the truth .

sp.speaker: LEO
sp.p: suddenly whimperingOh Rejjyshe runs to him and kisses him

sp.speaker: REGINALD
sp.p: wrathfullyBe off .She returns weeping to her seat

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: petting Leo , but speaking to the company at largeBut isnt all this great nonsense ? What likelihood is there of any of us committing a crime ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: Oh yes , I assure you . I went into the matter once very carefully ; and I found things I have actually done — things that everybody does , I imagine — would expose me , if I were found out and prosecuted , to ten years ’ penal servitude , two years hard labor , and the loss of all civil rights . Not counting that I 'm a private trustee , and , like all private trustees , a fraudulent one . Otherwise , the widow for whom I am trustee would starve occasionally , and the children get no education . And I 'm probably as honest a man as any here .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: outragedDo you imply that I have been guilty of conduct that would expose me to penal servitude ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: I should think it quite likely , but of course I dont know .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: But bless me ! marriage is not a question of law , is it ? Have you children no affection for one another ? Surely thats enough ?

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: If it 's enough , why get married ?

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Stuff , Sinjon ! Of course people must get married .UneasilyAlfred : why dont you say something ? Surely youre not going to let this go on .

sp.speaker: THE GENERAL
sp.p: Ive been waiting for the last twenty minutes , Alfred , in amazement ! in stupefaction ! to hear you put a stop to all this . We look to you : it 's your place , your office , your duty . Exert your authority at once .

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: You must give the devil fair play , Boxer . Until you have heard and weighed his case you have no right to condemn him . I 'm sorry you have been kept waiting twenty minutes ; but I myself have waited twenty years for this to happen . Ive often wrestled with the temptation to pray that it might not happen in my own household . Perhaps it was a presentiment that it might become a part of our old Bridgenorth burden that made me warn our Governments so earnestly that unless the law of marriage were first made human , it could never become divine .

sp.speaker: MRS BRIDGENORTH
sp.p: Oh , do be sensible about this . People must get married . What would you have said if Cecil 's parents had not been married ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: They were not , my dear .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: } { Hallo ! REGINALD } { What d'ye mean ? THE GENERAL } { Eh ? LEO } { Not married ! MRS. BRIDGENORTH } { What ?

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: rising in amazementWhat on earth do you mean , Bishop ? My parents were married .

sp.speaker: HOTCHKISS
sp.p: You cant remember , Cecil .

sp.speaker: SYKES
sp.p: Well , I never asked my mother to shew me her marriage lines , if thats what you mean . What man ever has ? I never suspected — I never knew — Are you joking ? Or have we all gone mad ?

sp.speaker: THE BISHOP
sp.p: Dont be alarmed , Cecil . Let me explain . Your parents were not Anglicans . You were not , I think , Anglican yourself , until your second year at Oxford . They were Positivists . They went through the Positivist ceremony at Newton Hall in Fetter Lane after entering into the civil contract before the Registrar of the West Strand District .
